content.title: Neural Networks for Ultrasensitive Nuclear Measurements
content.rating: 4: Ok but not good enough - rejection
content.review: I think the problem you are addressing is quite interesting. What I think is missing in the paper is a clear description of what kind of data you are dealing with. What is a basic unit, is it sequential, what kind of dimensionality is it, are dimensions interpretable.  In the paper you are referring to "pulses" but I am not sure I can derive much just from that. My main reservation, however, is that I have a problem seeing how this paper fits under late-breaking developments, very novel ideas or position papers category.
content.confidence: 5: The reviewer is absolutely certain that the evaluation is correct and very familiar with the relevant literature

content.title: Straightforward application
content.review:
This paper proposes the application of feedforward neural networks to a binary classification problem of the occurrence of radioactive decay events. The classifiers obtain close to 100% accuracy on some of the test sets. There are no technical innovations beyond the novel application, and the only baseline is a threshold function on a single feature. Given the high performance, it is plausible that the problem can be solved with any machine learning method that can learn non-linear decision boundaries. 

The training set is constructed to be balanced between positive and negative examples, but the paper does not state whether the test sets are balanced, so F1 might be a more appropriate evaluation metric.

I don’t think that this paper makes sufficient contributions to be accepted to the workshop, as it does not offer anything substantial of interest outside a narrow application that can plausibly be solved with very simple machine learning methods.
content.confidence: 4: The reviewer is confident but not absolutely certain that the evaluation is correct

content.title: Review
content.review: This paper apply a feed-forward neural network to classification of pulses.  It do not demonstrate why this problem is hard and why it needs neural network. Also, it's not clear of the problem setup, e.g. what is the input features. It's also unclear to me what is the baseline here.
content.confidence: 4: The reviewer is confident but not absolutely certain that the evaluation is correct

content.title: ICLR 2018 Workshop Acceptance Decision
content.comment: Based on the reviews, this paper has not been accepted for presentation at the ICLR workshop. However, the conversation and updates can continue to appear here on OpenReview.
